pros: Colleagues are innovative, very smart, passionate, and pragmatic, and also dedicated to one another. The board of trustees and many large donors have tremendous wisdom and connections and are eager to help with more than just funding.  The executive team is solutions oriented.
cons: Growing rapidly and occasionally experiences growing pains.

cons: No process Lack of diversity in senior leadership

review_title: So much potential squandered by poor management
pros: Colleagues are generally smart, kind, and fun to work with Pretty good work-life balance and benefits The work and projects themselves are really interesting and impactful
cons: No project management to speak of, leading to unclear goals and difficulty assessing success Top heavy organization -- too many bosses talking amongst themselves Lack of clear internal structures and procedures and constant reorgs makes office politics really crucial to advancing your career, which is difficult in a remote environment DEI efforts are weak - focus on hiring POC at the entry-level and don't provide enough resources or support to retain or promote them

pros: Flexible Hours: EDF offers flexible working hours, allowing employees to have a better work-life balance and accommodate personal commitments. Low Pressure: EDF may have a work environment with less pressure compared to other organizations, allowing employees to work at a pace that suits them and promotes a healthy work-life balance.
cons: Lack of Project Management: EDF may have room for improvement in terms of project management, which could result in challenges such as unclear goals, inadequate resources, or inefficient coordination among team members. Low Compensations: EDF may offer lower salary raises and bonuses compared to industry standards, which could be a disadvantage for employees who value financial incentives or recognition for their performance.

job_title: Gift Officer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: -fundraisers work hand-in-hand with program
cons: -competitive to get a job

pros: - This internship was incredibly well paid - matching many entry level jobs in the industry. - The work was more than grunt work and assistance. There are real job functions for interns for legitimately valuable experience. - It's a great name to have on your resume, and WILL open doors. - Fully remote work setting for maximum convenience - EDF likes to hire from within, so an internship will help you get hired later down the line.
cons: Can feel a bit isolated from the rest of the organization. You will have to work pretty hard to make relevant internal connections. But it is doable.

pros: good stack for data scientist
cons: nothing to say about cons

pros: Fair and smart employees. Lots of focus on systems and processes.
cons: Can feel bureaucratic and does not always value creativity.

review_title: Mostly great people, interesting work, big name in the NGO space
pros: Some absolutely stellar people--dedicated, smart, collaborative, passionate. Because of its name recognition and reputation, it is relatively well-funded for an NGO.
cons: Internal politics are no joke. It's hard to advance unless you network with the important people. There are some huge egos in positions of power (alongside some really fantastic people), but even the smart ones don't have enough management training and you end up with great people doing interesting work who have poor management skills. Not across the board, by any means, but if you get stuck in one of those streams, it's very hard to advance your career. Also, regular reorgs make it stressful unless you have a good manager who can insulate you.

pros: The benefits are the best, from robust health benefits to unlimited vacation time and choice of hybrid or remote schedules. EDF’s compensation package is above standard in comparison to other nonprofits.
cons: Typical nonprofit environment, do a lot more with very little resources. While some managers are understanding and supportive, others are just absolutely unreasonable with their needs and requirements. Some tend to over work and push tight deadlines on their associates. There have been several times where I was pushed to work nights and weekends. A program manager even bothered me on vacation once because she wanted something done - I of course ignored her. I have even seen an associate wanting to leave early from work sick, and while on her way home, received several messages on Slack from a manager to complete specific tasks (that could have waited for another day) when she gets home. Burn out is an issue!!

review_title: Great place to build your career
pros: hybrid work schedule, promoting from within, professional development opportunities budget and stipend for continuing education, summer fridays, unlimited pto, excellent benefits
cons: high turnover in development for this position, unequal workloads amongst team members

job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Benefits, perks, safe environment. Diverse
cons: Career advancement, political views, bureaucracy

pros: EDF makes a positive impact around the globe and has incredibly skilled and passionate people working on critical issues. EDF also makes a point to invest in their employees and leadership is generally receptive to feedback.
cons: EDF is a large organization, so reaching out to find answers on items even as essential as your healthcare benefits can be a challenge. I wish the HR team took more initiative and care with orienting new employees and provided more detailed breakdowns on topics that they need to know for their roles/personal lives. I also think that the HR team should be more accountable for answering all emails sent to the general HR email, since that is one of the only ways to reach that department when individual questions come up and what they respond to seems selective at best.

pros: EDF is a fantastic place to work. The organization invest heavily in the professional development of staff, providing frequent growth opportunities through promotions, in-house leadership training and budget for external trainings. Purpose driven community that also knows how to have fun together. Great benefits!
cons: Work is constrained by grant cycles and funder interests.

pros: The best part of working at EDF are the people. You are able to interact with some of the brightest and smartest minds in the business. Everyone regardless of what level they are in the company, treat you like you are the same.
cons: I do not have any negative reviews on working at EDF.

pros: Great people and many opportunities to network.
cons: The organization is very big.

review_title: Great company, great people, and decent salary.
pros: The work you do is important, interesting, and often groundbreaking. You will work with a lot of driven and smart people from diverse backgrounds. EDF does a great job forming relationships with a wide variety of governments, organizations, and individuals.
cons: Can't think of any apart from the salary, which is great for a non-profit but still fairly lower than a private company.

pros: Motivating work that is well compensated. Great team of individuals all aspiring to making a better and more diverse world.
cons: None that I can think of.

pros: Good managers to progress. Good feedback.
cons: Equilibrium between private life and profressional

pros: Good benefits Good salary Remote work Mission
cons: Long hours Constant reorg Donor driven

review_title: Old school management, unwilling to change
pros: The people you work with are usually awesome. But you never stay at any company for the people.
cons: Too much work, or too little work. Pay sucks. Management is unwilling to change with the times, they want nothing more than to get people back in offices. Said return to office was "voluntary" but forces people back that don't want to go back because they're "essential." The offices are completely unneeded. Also - there's no personal career growth here. Career growth only happens by tenure. If you have 2 employees applying for a job, and one is the optimal choice because they work hard and have the skills needed, while the other does not but simply has been there much longer, they'll take the tenured employee over the skilled employee. Peter principle runs rampant here and people are leaving positions like crazy because of the poor management decisions. Super top heavy as well, and re-orgs don't do anything besides help people on top be even higher. Also, don't expect to get paid what you're worth, ever.

review_title: Toxic culture and management won't listen.
pros: EDF employees are some of the most fantastic people I've ever met. They care deeply. It's a shame that is taken advantage of. If you're a cis het white man (bonus points if you went to an Ivy), you'll likely be fine. Everyone else? Avoid.
cons: Toxic managers are encouraged. People who were outed as racist and misogynist in the reckoning of 2020 have only been empowered and promoted and now lead the org. Employee concerns about inequity, burnout, and a top-heavy structure are summarily dismissed. Too many people have stayed at the org too long, cultivating a fear of any kind of change. Junior staff are usually doing the jobs of 2-3 people, working outrageous hours, and not being properly compensated or titled. There's no transparency in decision-making, and any constructive feedback is discouraged (or outright punished). The focus is on protecting power rather than addressing harms.

job_title: Development Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Collaborative, worthy cause, brainstorming, benefits,
cons: Growth, workload, information sharing, work life balance

pros: Good platform with good reputations in base country, the US
cons: Regional offices operates differently from the headquarter

pros: Unlimited vacation and good benefits
cons: Not many opportunities for career growth

pros: I enjoy the mission-based work and collaborating with many of my colleagues.
cons:
A previous review from October 2021 touched upon this subject: the toxicity that continues to permeate some areas of the organization. That reviewer may have been describing the same program. 

Despite a process in which employees could submit comments and concerns to leadership in the aftermath of the murder of George Floyd and the subsequent reckoning on race that many organizations faced, staff who were well known to have caused trauma to multiple colleagues, including those of color, have continued to be promoted and given more responsibility, while others continue to perpetuate the toxic behavior that this process was supposed to have addressed. I can only assume a 'business decision' is the primary reason that allows bad actors to continue to thrive at EDF. 

A member of program leader with a long and well-known record of causing harm, especially to employees of color by among other things, taking credit for direct reports and other programs' work on a regular basis, lying about their experience, exaggerating to higher-ups on work that really hasn't been done in the ways in which they have been described, promoting primarily those who kiss up (and who happen to be mostly White colleagues), dismissing the suggestions of colleagues of color, and outright shouting down to a direct report of color, has been permitted to thrive at the organization. 

This person's toxic behavior is responsible for pushing out a number of EDF staff, particularly those of color. Two direct reports (well, one just now) also displayed similar behavior, bullying staff who do the actual work since apparently, this role is largely to report out on work done by others. The rationale given for the since-departed direct report was that it was done as part of restructuring when it was common knowledge that this individual perpetuated racist microaggressions and was outride rude to many of this person's direct reports and colleagues within the Program.

pros: Remote work and meaningful focus
cons: sometimes depressing to overthink about climate issues

pros: Pretty flexible with work/life balance, good benefits
cons: They play favorites, and it’s allowed because the review and compensation process is not good. You could see one person move up multiple levels in a short timeframe while others get stuck at a certain level even if they’re doing the same work.

review_title: Great organization, great people, great mission
job_title: Associate Vice President, Membership Consulting in Washington, DC
pros: Rewarding work. Mission driven. Super smart people who care about the work and each other.
cons: Working toward better transparency in how different positions are banded and compensated. Lots of work, people are driven and a lot is put on their plates.

review_title: Management enables the toxic culture, so don't even bother
pros: The mission is what drew me in. Summer Fridays is nice too.
cons:
Teams and managers have analysis paralysis. Decisions just do not get made, no matter how time sensitive or important they are. They hide behind "consensus building" when it's really about avoiding blame.

Working from home did not alleviate the office politics issues, it only exacerbated them.

Like many nonprofits, the relationship between the organization and its employee base is extractive. The expectation is that, because the mission is important to you personally, you will be willing to deal with long hours and under market pay. 

There are known problem managers who the org protects. Overall, it is a very corporate environment.

review_title: A great place to build a career in climate
job_title: Project Manager in New York, NY
pros: Huge platform to gain exposure, meet experts in your field, and build up credibility as an environmental expert. Many opportunities internally to innovate.
cons: Compensation not competitive with emerging opportunities in climate. Rigid bureaucratic structure can slow upward growth.

pros: I enjoyed my time at EDF. It was an inspiring place to work, surrounded by smart, driven, friendly people that truly want to do good. It also had a great work-life balance (at least my team) and I never felt that there was any pressure to overwork.
cons: As a relatively big organization, what you do can feel a bit restricted as more junior staff. Even if you want to take initiative and do more, it can be hard to figure what you can do and how to make that happen. It can be hard to know what work is already being done in other teams and unclear who to ask or check with to do the work. But this is not specific to EDF, but a general limitation of bigger organizations.

pros: Mission critical, external reputation and funding

pros: We joke that EDF is "an organization full of class presidents." Employees are held to a high standard and evaluated based on results and achievements, not hours worked. Combines the best of a competitive environment (everyone is so talented and wants to impress everyone else) with the best of a collaborative environment (people are generally willing to help others and most projects are managed by the subject matter expert rather than the highest-ranking person). Salary and benefits are pretty good - by nonprofit standards I'd even call them great. The org is run like a business and has a fairly corporate feeling environment. Upper management does not tolerate dysfunction and routinely uses surveys and consultants to make sure we don't have any, and fix it if we do. Staff are friendly and a lot of folks socialize after work, but a lot of folks don't, and either one is fine. There is little to no gossip or interpersonal drama. Turnover is low but we've been growing for several years in a row so there's a good mix of folks with 10 or 20 years' tenure and plenty of new folks every year, too. Because we're growing and adding new positions all the time, a lot of folks have been able to turn a broad job description into an increasingly specialized one over time as new staff members are added to distribute work to.
cons: HR department is the only department that has a lot of turnover. They are often short-staffed and it can be hard to get assistance with benefits/questions in a timely manner.

pros: Most people here are passionate and smart.
cons: There are way too many VPs and a huge gap between the executives and the entry to mid level employees.

review_title: Fun place to work,  interesting balance between science and policy

cons: Office can get a bit lonely and isolating, Strong ivory tower vibes. High management turnover is very slow.

cons: Pay lower than industry standard for position

pros: Pays well and the work is fulfilling

review_title: Seems like a cool place to work but do not accomplish much
pros: Good work-life balance and generally fun, younger staff, especially in the larger offices. Your experience completely depends on your manager and program. I had some of the best managers and some of the worst. There is no management training for new managers and there are a lot managers managing a lot of people who are not effective managers.
cons: Extreme lack of transparency into human resources, promotions, compensation, and the organization overall. Everything is driven by money. They will do anything for a dollar even compromise project goals. If you do not have money for something new that you want to do then you will not make it past the first conversation with your boss and no one will help you find the money even though there is an entire department dedicated to finding and securing funding for projects. They pride themselves on being "entrepreneurial" which may have been true 20-30 years ago but not any more. This organization operates/acts more like a corporation than a nonprofit. Not the place for someone who wants to do something very different and is very idealogical/passionate. The wasting of resources, time/money, is also unbelievable...extravagant meals, events, salaries, offices, etc. They discuss "diversity" like white ivory-leaguers, they discuss it but do not do anything about it...by far the least diverse (ethnically, economically, socially, experientially) organization I have ever seen or been a part of in my career.

review_title: Good organization but needs some help
pros:
-Great mission and cause to work for
-More corporate than most non profits, more organized
-Excellent flexibility and work-life balance
cons:
-Organization needs to invest in staff and training- management could use some help
-Lack of upward mobility, especially for junior level staff- the organization fails to hire within 
-EDF doesn't always live up to its values- the lack of diversity, in terms of ethnicity and thought evidences this
-Not as progressive or innovative as the organization touts itself to be

review_title: Passionate People, Interesting Work, Some Growing Pains
pros:
-Well-established NGO that does not have to be struggling for sources of financing, which allows flexibility in the scope of work done.
-Higher level program staff is full of accomplished individuals who are experts in their field, and yet nonetheless remain more or less accessible to their junior staff.
-Relatively flat structure when it comes to information sharing and work assigned to junior staff, which allows one to build a good work portfolio and learn about what the organization is doing across all levels.
-Good work-life balance for the most part: Most people work 9 to a little past 5, others are working evenings and weekends but this depends on the team.
cons:
-Due to its size and ambiguity as to hierarchy when it comes to certain programs, decision-making  is complicated and sometimes based on consensus, which slows EDF down to the point of being reactive rather than proactive at times.
-Sometimes management is based in a different office from where one is working, which can be a source of mis-communication and slow down as people are in these cases accessible only by phone or email.
-Managers in programs are more program area specialists than managers, which may lead to management inefficiencies.

pros:
-Really passionate colleagues 
-Lots of opportunity to learn and really dive into environmental issues
-Pretty good work life balance 
-Typically flexible with wfh
cons:
-Upper management is insanely bureaucratic, and HR is basically a revolving door
-You basically need to have taken on extra work for 6 months-1 year before you'll get a promotion. There's an expectation that you have to "prove" you can do it, instead of going off of previous works and merits 
-Pay isn't great
-Internal candidates are not prioritized at all for open roles. I know of multiple people who applied to a different internal positions on another team and never even heard from HR, or heard that they weren't continuing with interviews. These are your colleagues! Where is the courtesy of a 2 second email?
-Expectation for a lot of travel in low budget situations (ie sharing a hotel room with a colleague). Not to mention the hypocrisy of upper management flying across the country for a one day meeting...

pros: Incredibly kind, laid back group of people, excellent to work with, friendly and comfortable office environment with a good sense of humor. The company offers a lot of little perks, good benefits, and when you travel, the company puts you up at some of the nicest hotels. The organization is effective at what it does. Overall, I enjoyed working there.
cons: At the organizational level, program staff are treated as individuals while support staff are treated as anonymous and expendable, which I think makes it hard for the organization to retain talented staff at the lower rungs and train them up. Middle and upper operations is dysfunctional and over paid. I'd say that EDF is a GREAT place to work if you are program staff, a GREAT place to work if you are early-career support staff and have lower expectations, but frustrating if you are well-educated in a support position and want to see your education paying off.

review_title: EDF is a relaxed place to work where you feel like you are doing good things with good people
pros: I think the best reasons to work for EDF has to be the atmosphere. The NYC office is extremely laid back, everyone is very friendly. The employers are very understanding of your personal life and time and don't want you to revolve your life around the job. As for the office itself, it is in a great location in the heart of the Flatiron district. The office has a very open floor plan with high ceilings that help prevent you from going stir crazy and It also consists of 4 floors and 3 kitchens with some of the most amazing views of the city I've ever seen
cons: The downside of working at EDF has to be the leadership and continuity of the missions. Often it seemed there was no direct resolve in the work in we were doing.

review_title: Great Mission, but many pros and cons...
job_title: Project Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great mission, awesome flexibility, annual merit increases, possibility of travel, offices all across the US (and in major cities), ability to work remotely, decent benefits!
cons: Hard to grow professionally internally, no managerial support (no toolkits for those who have direct reports), no transparency on hiring bands (titling and compensation), no consistencies across the organization on processes and procedures as well as compensation and promotions, no pay adjustments for cost-of-living.

review_title: Fun, intellectual, energetic place to work where everyone is passionate about what they do.
pros: The Fun Committee, The annual all staff retreat, Working with some of the smartest and most hard working people around (definitely no slackers), Being part of a great machine working towards an awesome social cause, Being part of an ethical company that values employees, And the fact that EDF is growing provides great opportunity for creating your own career path. Also EDF alumni go off to do some great things.
cons: With rapid growth some folks are let into the org and they don't necessarily have a passion for the environment but rather a passing interest. This sort of dilutes the passion-factor a little. Also some folks are promoted to manager status when they're not fully equipped to manage people.

pros: I felt like part of the team at EDF. I at first was given simple tasks but then once I demonstrated my research and editing abilities, I was able to take on more complex projects. I got to know a decent amount of employees in other divisions, and really enjoyed the Brown Bag lunches which were led by employees in other EDF offices. Very cool office environment/design. I definitely learned a lot about my field and appreciated not having my time wasted.
cons: Because a lot of the work my team was doing depended on a state's government, not a lot of progress was made due to unorganized state databases/websites. There doesn't seem to be any guarantee or preference for hiring interns from EDF for full-time positions.

review_title: There has not been a better sense of teamwork in the Development support team but management could use a few pointers.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: great Development support team. they have great communication with each other, and great sense of teamwork. they are willing to lend a hand when needed, band together to execute projects, and they are not only colleagues but become friends as well. they look out for your best interest along with the best interest of the department to further the success of the company.
cons: Development management team lacks that communication and teamwork. management team cannot articulate their needs, they can only articulate what is wrong after assigning a task without direction.

job_title: Climate Corps Fellow in Chicago, IL
pros: Excellent consulting experience to further strengthen a broad set of skills. Fellows have a lot of responsibility and opportunity to positively impact their company. Good way to switch careers into sustainability, and a few EDF fellows have gone to work full-time for their host. Well-organized and thoughtful matching process.
cons: Matching decisions are made later in the year, although this also means you can have a good plan A back-up if you don't want to take any fall MBA internship offers. The training experience is a great way to meet other EDF fellows, although EDF continues to refine the process since it's hard to meet training needs for such a diverse group.

pros: Great benefits, fancy offices, intelligent people, some are really nice and care about their work and the environment.
cons:
Where do I start?
- HR is a mess and your enemy. Beware. I hear they fired the whole department and things are shifting, hopefully for good.
- Inequality at all levels, inside and outside: disparity in compensations between upper management and junior level is outrageous. Your boss will make more than double, and his/her boss the same, up the chain.. This is combined with little room for promotions and development internally. Outside? EDF chooses to work with and for conservatives, white, and privileged folks.
- Some mid-level managers are well intended, but they lack the training to manage. They have no idea how to do it and its a shame. Again, this goes back to HR.

review_title: Great mission, highly effective, but could be better.
pros: Perhaps the most effective environmental NGO to work at the intersection of environment, markets, and business. Most employees feel like they have an ability to shape the national dialogue on environmental issues and the organization is creative in it's approach.
cons: There is no clear path for advancement within the organization, so it's up to employees to "figure it out" and make opportunities happen for themselves.  Compensation for employees that rise up within the organization does not keep pace with new employees.

review_title: A great place to work, but you will need much more expertise if you want to make your way up.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Some of the best people I've ever worked around. Both kind and impressive professional backgrounds. If you are highly interested in environmental issues, this is the place to be.
cons: Difficult to make your way up if you are working as an administrator. If you are a scientist, economist, lawyer or environmental expert, than you will make out just fine. People who are just starting out will want to consider getting their masters, MBA and/or PhD before making their way up the ladder here.

pros: EDF has provided ample career advancement, and given me the opportunity to really choose what I wanted to work on and explore what intersts me most. There's excellent comraderie amongst employees, and a strong sense of purpose.
cons: The organization has a strong consensus culture, which can make it difficult to finalize decisions on the fly. To be fair, management is working to solve the problem.

review_title: Great place to work...except when it's not
pros:
The organization does cool, important stuff.
Most employees are smart and intense and dedicated to making the world a better place.
The organization is focused strategically on getting stuff done.
Risk taking is often supported.
Lots of change.
cons:
Lots of change.  
Long hours and you're always on-call.
Things can go from great to terrible without warning.
Employees are disposable - I saw a number of people who were seemingly solid employees get systematically pushed out.  It was an ugly process and people left angry and confused.
Management is spotty.  Most managers are subject experts and don't do much managing.

review_title: Half great, half not so great
pros: Great perks and benefits, most people are awesome.  Good opportunity for work life balance. My team was a group of amazing people.
cons: The lack of diversity is unfortunate. There is no growth potential for staff hired at lower levels. Senior leadership just don't care about what happens to low level staff.  HR has blown through people like toilet paper, Finance is a hot mess,  and Fred refuses to address any of these issues.

review_title: it was a good place to work
pros:
-hardworking colleagues.
-great reputation
-the issues and mission are really worthwhile
-great location in san francisco 
-you feel proud working there.
cons: mmmmm, some of the management are very corporate oriented, and not as edf-mission driven as others. also, everyone but the admin staff are treated really well. if you're admin, then be prepared for a life of fetching sodas and filling out endless, ever-changing expense and credit card reports (every few months, the financial team changes, and with every change, they change or update the reports and charge codes.)

review_title: The smartest team you'll ever work with
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: EDF is well resourced and laser focused on delivering results. My coworkers were some of the smartest and most dedicated people I've ever met. Their commitment to win-win solutions and science-based methods is really inspiring.
cons: It can be difficult to see an actual career path there. In part, this is because people stay there for decades, which is really a compliment. At the same time, many people have to leave the organization for a while and return at a higher position.

pros: Very smart people and great mission. EDF has good benefits and tried to balance work with family and life. Shorter work week and generous vacation.
cons: No growth. There is no career potential here. Promotions are only for leadership. Lot of turnover of bright young staff - they hire from ivy leagues in lowly positions, stymie their growth till they get tired of waiting and leave. Same with middle management - either you are let go because of no funding or because there is no career path.

pros: EDF has very smart people who obviously care about making a positive difference. EDF also provides an excellent benefits package.
cons:
EDF is an extremely liberal organization staffed by people who think they are moderates. There is no diversity of thought from management who almost go out of their way to hire far left staffers. At EDF diversity only means skin color. EDF would be wise to follow Pew's model especially since so much of the money they raise comes from Republican donors. And this is why management puts on a bipartisan facade when meeting with its board and donors. 

The few conservatives on staff either hide their views or quickly learn that their input and analysis will be completely ignored and dismissed if it dares contradict some sacred liberal belief. Many of the goals at EDF are noble but management is so partisan and protective of Democratic interests that they will sacrifice their own agenda if it dares to upset other liberal NGOs or any Democratic politician in DC. For example, EDFs scientists determined fracking is safe and does not harm the water table yet their official statements were much less supportive so as not to upset the left. During cap and trade no one at EDF ever mentioned or discussed climategate because management primarily gets their news from MSNBC so they put their blinders on and pretended the scandal didn't exist. Then they were flabbergasted when climategate led to the death of their cap and trade bill. Most sadly, EDF management caved go the fascist voices on staff who refused to attend their annual retreat because it was being held at a beautiful hotel complex with a pro-American theme where Pat Robertson had a small stake in ownership.

Lastly, no one advances up the chain unless their ideology comports with managements almost like a religious litmus test.

review_title: Summer Internship - A great opportunity if you seek out your own challenges
pros: The Austin office has experts from a variety of backgrounds, including biology, engineering, economics, business, geology, and law.  The office is very laid back (especially in the summer, I'm told) and work hours are flexible.  Once you demonstrate that you are a serious employee, there are great opportunities to take on a prominent role in research.  I was able to attend City Council hearings and meetings with other environmental groups, and my research was regularly used on official EDF business.  Best of all, nearly everyone is friendly and engaging.  I developed several valuable connections that have lead to promising job prospects--and not just in Austin.  Highly recommended (especially at $12/hour)!
cons: As a motivated and passionate person, the office was sometimes too laid back for my tastes.  I found myself doing more work than some of my "bosses" on some occasions--not because I was told to work harder, but because they weren't as dedicated to producing results as myself.  Also, make sure you actively try to seek out work that interests you.  When I first arrived, they would have been more than happy to give me somewhat brainless tasks to be completed in my little office for the duration of the summer.  But because I pushed and nagged until I got work that was engaging, they were more than happy to comply.  I got the sense that the full-time employees didn't trust interns to be effective and dedicated, but once I proved to them that I was capable, they shoveled over a great deal of responsibility.

review_title: Very strong people, mission, network, and commitment to results
pros: Bright people, reasonable work-life balance, exciting projects, competitive compensation, entrepreneurial, taking cutting edges to solve the most difficult problems, has a diverse and helpful network that is used for fundraising but also advancing program goals, good focus on getting tangible, measurable environmental results, unusual discipline for a non-profit organization
cons: Difficult to move up, some lack of transparency into management decisions, need to improve cross-programmatic work in some areas, tough to get a job, as it is a very competitive landscape with lots of applicants for almost every position that opens up

review_title: Great projects, great people, little transparency on salaries
pros: As the title says EDF has amazing environmental projects and the majority of the people who work at EDF tend to be great. The organization is very slowly trying to make progress to advance career development and employee retention but it still has a long way to go.
cons: There is no transparency or clear career path at EDF. Very few high level managers and directors are mentors and you have to be extremely pro active to get ahead.

review_title: Truly committed to protecting the environment and great people working together to find solutions
pros: Very outcome oriented, challenging yet also supportive.  Cares about you as a person as well.  Competitive culture, but in a good way.  People want to do well and get the support they need to do well.
cons: No clear path for advancement usually; mapping a career path over the long term is not obvious.  Kinda big, so feels a bit like you can get lost.  Making progress on diversity, but needs to do more.

pros: Great place to work.  Very professional staff working on and effecting change on a wide range of environmental issues. I've worked at several environmental nonprofits in the DC area and EDF is by far the best one I've worked for.
cons: No major cons that I can think of.

review_title: Mostly great, but retention is not a priority
pros: Effective organization with team spirit, respected in its field
cons: They don't do much to retain you in terms of training for what might be next for you or finding a place for you in the organization if your role or program ends. Expect to be layered.

review_title: Smart people with a disciplined approach. Steady but little upward mobility.
job_title: Communications Director in New York, NY
pros: Smart people with a disciplined approach. Good salary and benefits.
cons: Little upward mobility. Poor management and mentoring. You can come in and stay at the level you started at but very difficult to advance.

job_title: Research Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Great organization full of smart, hardworking, people.  I enjoyed my time there and learned a lot.  I left because there wasn't really a way for me to advance within the organization.
cons: Tough to get your foot in the door.  Tough to move up if you're not starting out in a fairly senior position already.

review_title: Stay away! Good intent + bad execution = no good
pros:
- People are generally nice and friendly     

- You feel like you’re doing good. Working at a nonprofit dealing with climate change definitely feels like positive karma     

- Offices are nice and website looks nice. EDF is well funded
cons:
What I’m going to say won’t be pretty, but needs to be said. If you’re reading this, I’m guessing that you are someone who cares about the environment and climate change, and wants to make a difference. That’s what led me to EDF before I learned all of this. Here’s why I believe you should look elsewhere.



Many cons have been touched upon already, so I won’t spend too much time on them.     
- Lack of diversity and high turnover in the HR department [see review on 10/16/2018]     

- Different treatment of people working in the “programs” (basically people who do the science, research, or advocacy work) and people working in “operations” (people who do everything else that keeps the nonprofit running) [10/31/2018]

The following things are bigger issues that have been touched upon less. It took me over a year at EDF to gradually figure these out. The big two that were most important for me are:     

- Slow career progression: This will be especially relevant if you are young, ambitious, and itching to make a difference in your career. Career growth is slow and most of the work for lower-level employees just isn’t very interesting, challenging, or important. During my time at EDF, I felt strong cognitive dissonance between the company’s big-picture mission and the pointlessness of my day-to-day duties. From talking with others, this was a common feeling.     

- Lack of talent: Job satisfaction depends a LOT on the quality of the people you are surrounded by (especially your direct boss), how much responsibility you’re able to take on, and your rate of learning. The reality of how the world works is that money is important and non-profits do not pay very well, so they’re not able to attract the best talent. For me personally, the lower pay was a tradeoff I was willing to make (and did make), but it wasn’t until later that I realized pay is also a proxy for how much the organization values you, how much responsibility they give you, and the quality of the people you will be surrounded by. These are far more important, and should not be overlooked.     



Many of the other issues I saw can be traced back to the unavoidable fact that nonprofits, even ones as well-funded as EDF, are dependent on funding. In EDF’s case, funding comes from individual donors and foundations. I believe this is the source of, or at the very least contributes to, all sorts of interesting phenomena.     

- Too self-congratulatory: I have never come across a company with stronger corporate kool-aid than EDF. There’s a lot of patting oneself and each other on the back going on. Admittedly, EDF does get wins like publishing a new study on methane or challenging one of President Trump’s many anti-environment antics in court…but the level of celebration makes you think that they solved climate change already. Alas, we have a long way to go (~400 years at our current rate, according to a March 2018 MIT technology review article). I understand that celebrating wins is necessary for employee morale and keeping the donors happy, but it feels excessive and there’s a level of critical self-reflection on what could be done better that’s missing.     

- Pointless work that doesn’t lead anywhere: A lot of work seems like it’s only being done for the sake of it, with not enough attention paid to ROI and whether it SHOULD be done. For example, a lot of time is spent writing blog posts, adding to EDF’s website, and making pretty maps and graphs that very few people will ever look at.     

- Generally too much emphasis on form over substance: There was a ton of buzz about the “next wave of environmentalism” at the company’s annual retreat – basically, harnessing new tech like AI, blockchain, IOT, etc. to advance environmental issues. Not a bad idea, but people are doing it already in academia and industry (see: Silicon Valley), and it seems like these are more buzzwords for EDF than actionable goals.     

- Inefficient use of resources: EDF does not have an endowment, so dollars in must equal dollars out at the end of the fiscal year. This leads to lavish spending in the form of office renovations, flying people in to give talks, long lunches at expensive restaurants, etc. This was a bit of a bummer because the money is coming out of donors’ pockets, and one can’t help but feel that it could be put to better use with increasing pay, attracting better talent, advancing new initiatives, or any number of other areas.     



A final word on career paths and the tradeoffs of EDF:
Any job has tradeoffs. In my mind, EDF’s allure of making a difference just isn’t worth it for junior employees when balanced against the limited responsibility, talent, rate of learning, and career progression. This is why I would not work there, and why I think you too should look elsewhere. There is a place for EDF and other nonprofits in the world, but if you’re young, smart and ambitious, you will find a more fulfilling and impactful career elsewhere.     

By nature of not being the final decision maker and having limited funding, there is only so much that nonprofits such as EDF can do. Climate change is one of the biggest problems of our time, and deep decarbonization of energy will require both deploying existing technologies at massive scale (solar, wind, storage, etc) and developing, commercializing, and deploying technologies that do not yet exist (long duration energy storage, cheap and reliable nuclear, etc). Any number of other paths would be more “impactful” for the environment over the course of a lifetime than EDF. I put my money where my mouth is and urge you to do the same.

review_title: Driven and smart staff; excellent mission
job_title: Senior Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: The staff are smart, driven and really care about making the world a better place. EDF is highly effective and as staff it really feels like you're a part of having an important impact.
cons: Typical nonprofit organizational issues - funding dictates priorities and these can shift when grantors change their priorities. This can be frustrating for program staff.

pros: Staffers are mostly well-intentioned; work largely focuses on macro-scale policy issues; the work environment was easy, despite the fact many staffers believe it to be a high-pressure workplace.
cons:
EDF is mostly play-acting at doing real environmental work.  They view themselves as rainmakers, when, in reality, they're mostly just standing outside the halls of power shouting inanely.  I worked on several efforts to challenge permits issued by USACE and state agencies with delegated EPA authority.  Staff scurried around busily for weeks in prep for trial, thinking they were on the cusp of victory over the evil agencies.  After our counsel got crushed in court by the agency SMEs, they consoled themselves by reassuring us all that we were fighting nobly against evil polluters, even though the agency folks were at least as committed to environmental quality as anyone on our staff. 

EDF staff often loses in fights against government entities because they're blinded by their own arrogance.  They think because they have a law degree or a bachelor's from Brown that the state is going to forfeit their position out of fear.  In reality, we usually went to trial against SMEs who were at least as educated as our staff, and certainly more steeped in policy, given that they wrote it.  And there was scant little effort to engage agency staff in discussion as people.  I pushed for this, knowing that having some friendly contacts in government would have helped us immensely to understand policy and the soft spots in it.   Moreover, I knew we needed to recruit some agency folks to come work on our side and bring their insider's knowledge with them.  Nothing would have helped us more.

As it was, management seemed content to lose case after case in the district and administrative law courts.  What EDF amounted to, then, was a convoluted means of spending the donations of their wealthy benefactors with nothing substantive to show for it, a farce of environmental advocacy.

review_title: Great place to work, important mission. Smart people, but less than they think.
pros: Great atmosphere, with smart, pragmatic people who value innovation and do not adhere to the typical dogmas of environmentalism. Good work-life balance. Wonderful focus on science-based environmentalism, including economics.
cons: An organisation that is a little too full of itself, and sometimes lacks perspective. HR is often unresponsive, except when it comes to letting people go. Upper management in some programs are disengaged from their operational staff.

pros:
- intellectual curiosity
- mission and results driven
- smart and passionate people
- capable, respectful executive staff
- sense of humor 
- work/life balance
- benefits
- open to criticism
cons:
- lack of autonomy
- afraid of risks
- ageism
- gossip and cronies
- rarely hires from within 
- places financial burdens on program budgets
- afraid of the new

pros: This is a great org to work for if you care about pragmatic solutions to environmental problems.  Middle management is generally great in my experience, caring about their employees and generally seeking to encourage professional growth.
cons: Upper management is a little detached, and often times the pressure to fund raise overtakes other work priorities.  While personal and professional growth is encouraged there are limits and promoting from within seems rare.

review_title: Great organization that balances competing priorities for the planet and people.
pros: Very pragmatic, yet innovative organization to work for. Seeks to accomplish large-scale environmental change with as many partners as possible. Strong organizational culture. Supportive work environment. Upper management/executives are open and receptive. Strong leadership throughout organization.
cons: For new hires, it can be tricky to integrate into and navigate the organization. Programs and departments operate in silos and there is less cross-departmental communications and coordination.

pros: I enjoyed my time at EDF.  It's a positive work environment with a lot of collaboration and opportunities for growth.  They made a strong effort for the whole staff to know about the programs and feel inspired about the mission.
cons: There were very few cons!  I had challenges with a manager for part of my time there, but was always able to turn to other staff as mentors.

review_title: Great job, but be careful with hosts
pros:
You can definitely learn a lot on the job and get great real world experience
They cover training and travel  
They offer a great chance for networking
Great Pay
cons:
Host organizations can be pretty unprepared
Host managers are sometimes not very involved, they'll leave the project totally in your hands

pros: A wealthy and mostly well run organization, a somewhat laid back attitude. Good health benefits, matched 401k after 3 mo.
cons: Difficult at times to know where you stand with your managers and team. Lots of turn over, even at the top. If you come in at an Entry Level position, only 1 in 30 have a chance of growing and moving up.

review_title: Good place to work unless you are part of the Operations Dept
pros:
Great mission for the organization
people are very passionate about the work they do
very well educated and intelligent people
cons:
HR group has had 98% turn over rate
Extreme communication issues internally
Massive amounts of dysfunction within the HR group has made for extremely toxic and frustrating work environment

review_title: Important work but confusing and inefficient organizational structure
pros: Passionate people who really care, doing meaningful and important work, well respected organization, idealistic yet practical in its approach to environmentalism
cons: Employees with donor connections run the show even if they are incompetent, typical bureaucracy to be expected from a big organization

review_title: Mix of large organization structure and mid-size office flexibility
pros: An excellent organization to work for in the areas where there is the largest funding. There is untapped potential in some areas that can be utilized more often, but the need goes to where the donations are greatest.
cons: Sometimes, the executive management team focuses too much on a few individual contributors as compared to the team that took them to success.

review_title: Experience really depends on the department you’re in...
pros:
-Nice coworkers
-Fun retreat
-Great mission
-Decent pay
-Convenient office location
cons:
-Boring tedious work
-Inept management (Gifts dept)
-Programs work in silo
-Each dept applies company policies differently 
-Poor work life balance (gifts dept)
-unsupportive of/discriminates against pregnant employees

pros: Brilliant, passionate people working on research and projects that make a real difference. Superiors really cared about my progress but also gave me independence on my own project.
cons: When I was there years ago, the office space in San Francisco was quite antisocial, and people from different groups did not interact much at all. They were making strides change that, and I hope they have!

job_title: Project Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Incredibly caring and passionate employees
Very good benefits
cons:
Overall work/life is not balanced- everyone cares so much that work above and beyond normal business hours
Limited pathways for professional growth

review_title: Great work environment with capable collegues that are all passionate about many facets of the environment.
pros: It is a very professional work environment and your colleagues are always willing to share and collaborate their independent work.
cons: Management is always willing to listen but not often willing to move on policy which sometimes leaves them behind the curve. Overly cautious but nonpartisanship can be helpful later on.

pros: Smart, dedicated people passionate about finding solutions to the biggest environmental problems.
cons: Too bureaucratic, hierarchical, and self congratulatory.  Too fixated on upper management, leading to bottlenecks, lost opportunities, lack of efficiency.  Too many unnecessary fire drills.

review_title: Great Impact and Work Life Balance
job_title: Research Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Being surrounded by excellent thinkers with a real drive to make a difference.  Great flexibility and work-life balance, and high quality work benefits.
cons: The focus on project completion under tight timelines can mean that you sometimes have to work around the clock / on weekends, but management is good at compensating you for that extra time spent.

pros: Very smart, passionate people working on a great cause. They are thoughtful and open to new ideas.
cons: I was not impressed by the managers here. They tend to be well-respected in their fields, but were not ready to manage employees.

job_title: Membership Assistant/Leadership Team Liaison in Prospect, KY
pros: Full of smart people who care about saving the environment using practical means.  Great programs involving fisheries, wildlife, climate change.  Highly recommend working for this organization.
cons: Really cannot give a list of "cons" about this organization.  I wish I was still able to work for them.

pros: managers are very helpful, salary is good for an internship. Company is actively organizing networking activities and helping its fellows to build its career path.
cons: it is an Internship, difficult to land a job offer.

review_title: Environmental Defense Fund Climate Corps Fellow
job_title: Climate Corps Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Well-paid (compared to other internships), great experience, rich network of current and former fellows, and supportive engagement mangers
cons: EDF has a very competitive selection process and less than 10% of applicants usually get selected

pros: everyone is very passionate about their work which makes coming to work more fun and interesting
cons: Not too much room for growth or professional development which makes it hard to move up the ladder

review_title: Fabulous opportunity to foray into the corporate sustainability space.
pros: The fellowship offers an opportunity to build a fantastic network and hands-on project management experience. In addition, you also get great flexibility in shaping a solution to a pressing clean energy/environmental issue. All in all, a wonderful learning experience.
cons: No constrains faced during fellowship duration.

pros: I enjoy working with really intelligent and thoughtful people everyday
cons: salary compensation is low for entry level employees

job_title: New York Office in New York, NY
pros: Great central location, newly renovated office space.  Some genuine colleagues that care about the environment. Great work/life balance.
cons: Very high turnover from the Executive team on down. Prominent nepotism, cliquish & uninviting work environment, lack opportunities for professional development within the org.

review_title: Fun place to work, challenging environment.
pros: Great place to work. If you are concern about personal development, I would reccomend EDF. I learnt alot skill from my internship that I will be using in my full time job.
cons: Communication was an issue most of the time.

job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Relaxed, fun company, that works on a mission to help the planet.
cons: Bad communication among programs & managers, low moral, HR needs work,  very hard for advancement within organization.

pros:
The hiring process is long. 
EDF have an extensive network. 
The work they do is extremely influential, it is great to be part of that network now.
cons:
You could be placed in a project that might not be your first choice. 
Some projects are better managed than others.

pros: self-motivated, passionate, inspired, people who care
cons: typical non-profit underdeveloped operational resources. systems for tracking budgets, submitting for reimbursement or vendor payments, any HR related process - all unclear, outdated, incredibly complicated and very, very slow.

pros: Sharp people and important work
cons: It's apparent they invest all their money in senior management and are willing to let young employees leave

pros: They have a 35 hour work week, which means 9-5 with a 1 hour lunch. I was never tired at the end of the day with that schedule, and felt it was conducive to productivity.
cons: The people were strangely cold and many did not seem especially interested in actually protecting the environment. Very little sincere concern for environmental justice. Very little concern for the welfare or survival of non-human species.

pros: Kind hearted and smart employees. Good place to work if you are dedicated to finding practical wonky  solutions.
cons: Some programs are better than others. Limited advancement for people of color.

pros: exceptionally smart people.  strong commitment to excellence.
cons: not a very warm or welcoming culture.  Sink or swim environment.

pros: I had a good time working at EDF, the staff and other interns were friendly and easy to get along with.
cons: I only wish I got a little more practical writing experience instead of only doing research

pros: Focus on making real change in the world
cons: Staff is stretched thin which is making people less willing to help each other

review_title: Passionate people, pragmatic enviro ngo, bad salaries and inexistent career development for junior staff
job_title: Research Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: The people that work there are great, passionate and interesting; great colleagues.
cons: salary and lack of carreer development plan

pros: Wonderful people, great mission, lots of autonomy and creative thinking is encouraged.
cons: Career growth potential may be limited depending on your field; pay is good for non-profit but it is still a non-profit salary.

pros: Great opportunity to network with folks in the energy and sustainability industry
cons: Not any that I can think of

pros:
Passionate, hardworking teammates
Interesting programs
Mission-driven organization
cons:
Very little upward mobility 
High attrition rate among junior staff
Very divided programs - minimal interaction between

pros: The opportunities for women her are wonderful.
cons: I don't have any cons at this time.

review_title: Fast paced but full of potential
job_title: Senior Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Great company culture and goal setting. Opportunities for advancement if you perform well.
cons: Very fast paced. Sometimes job requires working outside of usual business hours. Siloed departments.

pros: Pays well. Get to work independently. Learn a lot about helping organizations improve energy efficiency. Proactive staff. Good for the environment.
cons: Have to pay for expensive training up front. Reimbursed later.

review_title: Great organization with great people working for a great cause
pros: Excellent in communications and advocacy.  A great place for professional development
cons: Lack of diversity both in thought and background

review_title: Challenging environment for entry to mid levels
pros: Wonderful learning organization where you learn everything you need / want to know about environmental management.
cons: There is very little buy in from upper management and Directors for new ideas.

pros: Working with motivated and passionated colleagues; great work life balance; flexibility
cons: Lack of cultural diversity; limited career opportunities

pros: professional development opportunities, good office environment depending where you are, friendly people
cons: little upward mobility for junior staff, high turnover in management, very corporate motives

pros:
Lots of attention from my supervisors
Was able to take my projects further than initially expected
Help was available when needed
cons: Office was a little slow moving at times

pros: Fun and smart people in all areas
cons: Not a lot of perks if you are contractor only worthy if they hire you as a full-time employee

review_title: Great work environment with a powerful mission
pros: Employees passionate about mission, supportive of work/life balance
cons: Disorganized management, sometimes offices outside NY/DC feel "less than"

pros: Committed staff who want to do good work to protect and preserve the environment.
cons: Management was a mess. Always restructuring and never seeming to get it right.

pros: EDF does a great job of bipartisan and engaging with the people, owners, companies who is affected by an issue. Great benefits.
cons: No management or leadership training and it is needed.

pros:
Amazing organization
Helpful and understanding colleagues
Great mission
Exposure to multiple fields
cons:
Not so great salary

pros: Environmental Defense is a great place to work for. The company does great stuff that is beneficial to future.
